comments.commentBody: Where do you think electricity comes from?  All cars run on electricity - from the spark plugs to the headlights.  It is simply more efficient and thus less expensive and more environmentally friendly to burn the fuel to generate the electricity at the user end rather than burn it across town and wire in the results.  Electrical power is lost over the distance generated from the user. That is what made the internal combustion engine such a miracle in the first place. Contrary to popular belief, the skies were smoggier in the late industrial ages right before the invention of the automobile.

As long as you actually saw the offense go down, and it transcends the level of "let them work it out themselves," then you need to put your child's needs and safety first. An 8-yr-old once pushed my then-4-yr-old down a slide at McD's, and not only did no parent come forth, I couldn't even tell who is parents were. I asked the older boy about it, gently, and he admitted that he had done it and that he didn't even know why he had done it. I had him point out his mom, and when I asked her about it, she shrugged and said, "Johnny, I've told you not to do that." And that was the extent of it. Later, when we were leaving, I saw her buying him a giant cookie. Not exactly how I would punish a repeat offender.

The whole episode brought home to me that no one is going to put my child's safety first if I don't, and that I don't give a rat's patootie if someone else is offended, as long as my conscience is clear regarding my own involvement. That said, it is important that kids learn to work out their own differences, so I think we need to be careful that we are intervening only if we saw what happened personally (as opposed to child hearsay), that the infraction really is worthy of intervention, and especially, if there is a significant age differential. Absent these criteria, there might be some value in teaching our own kids how to deal with potentially confrontational situations, but it sounds in this case as though F. acted appropriately.

One of the big problems you overlook (although I'm sure Apple didn't) is that Apple Messages pre-empts regular text messages. So if, not-so-hypothetically, I have an iPad and an Android phone, when someone I know sends me a 'text" from an iPhone, it prefers to go to Messages on my iPad (generally at my home) and not as a text message to my phone (generally with me). So I don't get those messages promptly anymore. I could fix this by getting an iPhone, which I'm sure is exactly the point.

The Hunger Games escaped my notice until very recently (today, as it turns out), but I can see the parallel with the Republican primaries.  We have a bunch of candidates, all from different Districts.  They appear to have been chosen at random, since they have no particular qualifications for the job.  They fight each other because they're starving, for food in the book, but for attention in the primaries.  There is much brutality, piling on, strange alliances, fatal errors, and entrails.  Lots of entrails.  In the end, the winner will be the only one left standing.  I hope the parallels end there, because the book has sequels and I don't think I could stand any more primaries.

The cycles of nature exist for our benefit, as well as to our detriment. If we live in synergy and/or harmony with nature, we prosper. It seems Santorum and his fellow "fundamentalists" wish to return to the middle ages, where another natural phenomenon culled the herd and imposed balance by "correcting" our population, namely the plague. As we cower before an eclipse and toss our our dead, our new Torquemada will be busy torturing folks on the rack for religious heresy (Gutenberg would have been his first victim, no doubt).  I, for one, can't wait to get suited up with new armor and mount my trusty steed, to ride off into the sunset (if I can still see it thru the smog) and fall off the edge of the flat earth.
